Transcript: Interviewer: Alright, howdy. I'm here to give you your mock interview for the position of "procurement officer lead". Uh, which doesn't have a lot of description- has a few notes. Um-

Interviewer: -oh, right off the first line- uh, what experience do you have in soliciting and negotiating contracts?
Veteran: None.
Veteran: I have not done any contract negotiations at all.
Interviewer: Ok. Uh, uh, so-
Interviewer: Wow, there is nothing in this job listing-
Veteran: Yeah I know, I read the same thing.
Interviewer: Yeah, um, do you have any experience with, uh, training and reviewing the works of-of-of your subordinates?
Veteran: Yes, yes I do, um, do I need to go into detail about this?
Interviewer: Yes, yes. Please do. Treat this like you would a normal interview, other than that I'm probably very inept [laughter].
Veteran: Ok, I just want to make sure how much experience you wanted. Uh, so yes, uh, in the Army I did, uh-
Veteran: -training, for those who were under me, at times, uh when I was specialist, I trained with privates-
Veteran: -and other specialists that I worked with.
Veteran: Especially when I worked at a, uh- and sergeants as well, when I did security.
Veteran: At [inaudible]. It's basically a giant blimp. And, um, part of my job, when I-when we were switching out within our rotation-
Veteran: -at the end of the deployment, was I had to train these people who were coming in, on how to do the job.
Veteran: And even those who were higher rank than me, still had to understand that I was the instructor, and at the time- even though they outrank me, I'm still the boss.
Veteran: They need to follow my instructions. I still had to be respectful to them, but they had to listen to me.
Veteran: And um, same thing for those who were also in the [inaudible] as well, I had to train them.
Veteran: Then, ten years at Reynolds and Reynolds, working at inventory department, and part of my job was to train new people.
Veteran: Uh, probably the biggest thing I did there was I trained a part time, high school girl who came in at 17 years old, first job-
Veteran: I remember this, because I had one week to train her on how to do a full-timer's job, entire thing-
Veteran: You know, I had 3 days to train her how to do this job, cause I was going on vacation for 2 weeks.
Veteran: And I got her trained up. She did it. She hated me for it, but she did it, and, uh-
Veteran: It led- it led to her, uh, recieveing awards in uh, uh praise for the hard work she did while I was off.
Interviewer: Cool. Well that leaves me-
Interviewer: That leads me to another good, general question. Uh, obviously she hated you for it, so you've had-had some level of conflict at the office. How do you deal with resolving conflict?

Veteran: -she was angry at me, but here it is- her first job- and you have 3 days to learn how to do a full-timer's job. And you're only supposed to be there part time.
Veteran: It was not fair for her. But-
Veteran: Yeah. Most-most learn any conflict can be solved by finding out, usually by talking, cause simple misunderstanding, uhm-
Veteran: -or, could be someone's just having a bad day, week, month.
Veteran: You're-
Veteran: If you have to ask to go higher than that, then- which I find it rarely does- then, uh, supervisors, managers can be brought in as needed.
Interviewer: Gosh, man, there is-
Interviewer: [inaudible], pulling from your resume-
Interviewer: Uh, tell me about your experience as being a recruitment officer for uh, [inaudible] Veterinary Hospital. Uh, what are your- what were your day-to-day tasks, what were-
Interviewer: -uh, things you did commonly during that job?
Veteran: So, normally, the job goes um- and this is before covid, during covid, and now-
Veteran: -uh, trucks come in- UPS, Fedex, unload the trucks, sort them packages, open them, check the items, against the um, packing lists that are included-
Veteran: -fill out any paperwork that needs to be done, such as if they're missing paperwork, I need to find out where they go to-
Veteran: -and deliver them to various parts of the hospital.
Veteran: Um, the other part of my job, is I go shopping for the hospital, so someone puts an order in for ground beef, ground turkey-
Veteran: -um, medicine that we need to pick up from HEB, or St. Joseph- paper towels, cleaning supplies- I drive all over town to find these items.
Veteran: Um, that's the main part of my job.
Veteran: Um, during covid, when A&M was on lockdown, uh-
Veteran: -at the very start of it, my job for almost 3 months- and Monday through Friday, no joke, was shopping.
Veteran: That was my sole focus, every day, to go out and find cleaning supplies, paper towels, clorox, hand wipes, sanitzier-
Veteran: -all day, almost every day, around Bryan-College Station area. That was my job, pretty much.
Interviewer: All of the things that are hard to find.
Veteran: Exactly, and we got to the point where i had to tell uh, supervisors and the higher ups at the vet hospital- the small and large animal-
Veteran: -"you're out of your mind", because they wanted a 12-pack of Bounty paper towels, that's it, just 12-pack.
Veteran: And going, "you're not getting this."You're gonna have to take either a single roll, or you're gonna have to take this other brand".
